title: Jeremiah Chapter 40 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 40 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 40 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 40.

questions.question: Who let Jeremiah go from Ramah after taking him captive?
options: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard
Baalis the king of the Ammonites
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:1 states that Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard let Jeremiah go from Ramah.

questions.question: What did the captain of the guard say God had pronounced upon the place?
questions.correctAnswer: This evil
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:2 states the captain of the guard said, 'The LORD thy God hath pronounced this evil upon this place.'

questions.question: Why did the LORD bring the evil upon the place?
options: Because they sinned and disobeyed God's voice
questions.correctAnswer: Because they sinned and disobeyed God's voice
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:3 explains the evil came because they sinned against the LORD and did not obey His voice.

questions.question: What choice was Jeremiah given by the captain of the guard?
options: To go to Babylon or go anywhere else he wished
To stay in chains or be free
To become a governor or a soldier
To return to Jerusalem or go to Moab
questions.correctAnswer: To go to Babylon or go anywhere else he wished
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:4 states Jeremiah was told he could go with the captain to Babylon or go anywhere else he wished.

questions.question: Where did Jeremiah go to dwell after being freed?
questions.correctAnswer: To Mizpah with Gedaliah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:6 says Jeremiah went to Gedaliah to Mizpah and dwelt with him among the people.

questions.question: Who was appointed governor over the cities of Judah by the king of Babylon?
options: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard
questions.correctAnswer: Gedaliah the son of Ahikam
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:5 and 40:7 state that Gedaliah the son of Ahikam was made governor over the cities of Judah.

questions.question: What did Gedaliah swear to the captains and their men?
options: Fear not to serve the Chaldeans and dwell in the land
To fight against the king of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Fear not to serve the Chaldeans and dwell in the land
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:9 states Gedaliah swore to them not to fear serving the Chaldeans and to dwell in the land.

questions.question: What did Gedaliah instruct the people to do with their wine, summer fruits, and oil?
options: Gather them and put them in vessels
questions.correctAnswer: Gather them and put them in vessels
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:10 instructs the people to gather wine, summer fruits, and oil and put them in vessels.

questions.question: True or False: All the Jews in Moab, Ammon, Edom, and other countries ignored the news about Gedaliah's appointment.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:11 and 40:12 state that all the Jews heard the news and returned to Judah to Gedaliah.

questions.question: Who warned Gedaliah that Ishmael had been sent to kill him?
options: Johanan the son of Kareah and other captains
Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard
Baalis the king of the Ammonites
questions.correctAnswer: Johanan the son of Kareah and other captains
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:14 says Johanan and the captains warned Gedaliah that Ishmael was sent to kill him.

questions.question: What was Gedaliah's response to the warning about Ishmael?
options: He sent a messenger to the king of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: He did not believe them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:14 states Gedaliah did not believe the warning about Ishmael.

questions.question: What did Johanan secretly ask Gedaliah permission to do?
options: To kill Ishmael without anyone knowing
questions.correctAnswer: To kill Ishmael without anyone knowing
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:15 shows Johanan asked Gedaliah to allow him to kill Ishmael secretly.

questions.question: Did Gedaliah allow Johanan to kill Ishmael?
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:16 shows Gedaliah refused and said Johanan spoke falsely of Ishmael.

questions.question: True or False: The captain of the guard gave Jeremiah victuals and a reward before letting him go.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:5 states the captain of the guard gave Jeremiah victuals and a reward.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Jeremiah 40:4: 'And now, behold, I loose thee this day from the chains which were upon thine ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: hand
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:4 says, 'I loose thee this day from the chains which were upon thine hand.'

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 40 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 40 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God's plan during difficult times. Based on Jeremiah 40, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God's sovereignty?
options: God's promises and judgments come true as He declares them.
God often changes His mind about His plans.
Human efforts alone determine the outcome of events.
One must avoid suffering by any means necessary.
questions.correctAnswer: God's promises and judgments come true as He declares them.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:2-3 shows that the LORD pronounced evil on Jerusalem because of sin, and He brought it to pass exactly as He said. This teaches us to trust God's sovereignty and that His words are sure.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 40:4-5 teach us about obedience and freedom in following God's guidance?
options: God gives us freedom to choose but provides guidance for our good.
We must blindly follow every human leader without question.
Freedom means doing whatever we want without consequences.
Obedience requires sacrificing every personal choice.
questions.correctAnswer: God gives us freedom to choose but provides guidance for our good.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah was released from chains and given a choice to go to Babylon or stay. The captain of the guard advised him to stay with Gedaliah or go where he saw fit, illustrating God’s respect for human freedom within His providential plan (Jeremiah 40:4-5).

questions.question: A believer feels isolated after hardship. Based on Jeremiah 40:6-7, what encouragement about fellowship and community can you offer?
options: God desires His people to dwell together and support one another.
Isolation is the best way to avoid temptation.
Faith is a private matter and does not need community.
Each person must care only for themselves.
questions.correctAnswer: God desires His people to dwell together and support one another.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah went to live with Gedaliah among the people remaining in the land, showing the value of fellowship and unity in times of trial (Jeremiah 40:6-7).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 40:9, how should believers respond to governing authorities and difficult circumstances?
options: Serve and respect authorities for your well-being.
Always rebel against any difficult leadership.
Seek to overthrow rulers by force.
questions.correctAnswer: Serve and respect authorities for your well-being.
questions.explanation: Gedaliah told the people not to fear serving the Chaldeans and to dwell in the land, promising it would be well with them. This teaches respect and submission to governing authorities when possible (Jeremiah 40:9).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 40 teach about contentment and diligence through the example of gathering produce?
options: Work diligently and be content with what God provides.
Wait passively for blessings without effort.
Gather wealth only for personal pleasure.
questions.correctAnswer: Work diligently and be content with what God provides.
questions.explanation: People gathered wine, summer fruits, and oil to store, showing responsible stewardship and contentment with God’s provision (Jeremiah 40:10, 12).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 40:11-12 encourage believers about restoration after exile or hardship?
options: God can restore His people and bring them back to fellowship.
Once exiled, there is no hope for return.
Hardship means permanent separation from God.
Restoration depends solely on human effort.
questions.correctAnswer: God can restore His people and bring them back to fellowship.
questions.explanation: Jews returned from many nations to Judah and to Gedaliah, showing that God brings restoration and unity after trials (Jeremiah 40:11-12).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to act rashly against an enemy. Based on Jeremiah 40:14-16, what biblical principle about patience and discernment can you share?
options: Do not act on unverified accusations; seek wisdom and patience.
Take immediate revenge to protect yourself.
Ignore all warnings and act without counsel.
questions.correctAnswer: Do not act on unverified accusations; seek wisdom and patience.
questions.explanation: Gedaliah refused to believe the report that Ishmael was sent to kill him and forbade Johanan from killing Ishmael, demonstrating trust, patience, and careful discernment (Jeremiah 40:14-16).

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah was forced to go to Babylon with the captain of the guard after being released from chains.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The captain of the guard told Jeremiah he could go to Babylon if he wished, but he was free to choose to stay anywhere else as well (Jeremiah 40:4).

questions.question: True or False: Gedaliah encouraged the people to serve the king of Babylon and live peacefully in the land.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Gedaliah swore to the captains and their men not to fear serving the Chaldeans and encouraged them to dwell in the land and serve the king of Babylon (Jeremiah 40:9).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "I will dwell at Mizpah to serve the ________, which will come unto us."
questions.correctAnswer: Chaldeans
questions.explanation: Gedaliah said he would dwell at Mizpah to serve the Chaldeans, indicating submission to Babylonian authority (Jeremiah 40:10).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 40 illustrate the importance of integrity and honesty in leadership?
options: Gedaliah’s refusal to believe false accusations shows integrity.
Leaders should always act on rumors.
Avoid all responsibility to prevent conflict.
questions.correctAnswer: Gedaliah’s refusal to believe false accusations shows integrity.
questions.explanation: Gedaliah refused to act on unproven claims about Ishmael and encouraged truthfulness and justice (Jeremiah 40:14-16).

questions.question: What practical lesson about generosity and provision can be drawn from the people gathering wine and fruits in Jeremiah 40?
options: Prepare and share resources responsibly in times of uncertainty.
Ignore future needs and live only for today.
Depend solely on others for provision.
questions.correctAnswer: Prepare and share resources responsibly in times of uncertainty.
questions.explanation: The people gathered produce to store and dwell in their cities, demonstrating wise stewardship (Jeremiah 40:10,12).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 40 teach about humility and contentment in difficult circumstances?
options: Be content with God’s provision and live humbly under His plan.
Always seek to change your situation by force.
Ignore God’s will and pursue your desires.
questions.correctAnswer: Be content with God’s provision and live humbly under His plan.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah stayed with Gedaliah and lived among the remnant, accepting God’s arrangement humbly (Jeremiah 40:6-10).

questions.question: A believer is fearful of serving under difficult leadership. Based on Jeremiah 40, what encouragement can you give about serving others and God’s authority?
options: Serving under authority can lead to peace and blessing.
Avoid all service under earthly rulers.
Serve only when leaders are perfect.
Service is optional and irrelevant to faith.
questions.correctAnswer: Serving under authority can lead to peace and blessing.
questions.explanation: Gedaliah encouraged the people not to fear serving the Chaldeans and promised it would be well with them, showing that faithful service under authority is beneficial (Jeremiah 40:9).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 40 teach about perseverance through trials and trusting God's timing?
options: Trust God's timing even when it means waiting and enduring hardship.
Give up when situations are difficult.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God's timing even when it means waiting and enduring hardship.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah’s release and choice to remain in the land with Gedaliah show trust and perseverance despite captivity and uncertainty (Jeremiah 40:1-6).

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 40 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 40.

questions.question: Who was appointed governor over the cities of Judah by the king of Babylon?
questions.correctAnswer: Gedaliah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:5 states that the king of Babylon appointed Gedaliah son of Ahikam as governor over the cities of Judah.

questions.question: What does Nebuzaradan offer Jeremiah when he sets him free from chains?
options: Freedom to choose where to go
questions.correctAnswer: Freedom to choose where to go
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:4 explains that Nebuzaradan loosens Jeremiah from his chains and gives him the choice to go to Babylon or anywhere else.

questions.question: What reason does Nebuzaradan give for the calamity that has come upon Jerusalem and Judah?
questions.correctAnswer: Sins against the LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:3 states that the evil came because they sinned against the LORD and did not obey His voice.

questions.question: Which group of people returned to Judah to join Gedaliah after hearing of his appointment?
options: Jews from Moab, Ammon, Edom, and other countries
questions.correctAnswer: Jews from Moab, Ammon, Edom, and other countries
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:11-12 show that Jews from various nations returned to Judah to be with Gedaliah.

questions.question: What advice does Gedaliah give to the captains and their men regarding serving the Chaldeans?
options: Fear not to serve the Chaldeans
questions.correctAnswer: Fear not to serve the Chaldeans
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:9 records Gedaliah urging the people not to fear serving the Chaldeans for their well-being.

questions.question: What does Gedaliah instruct the people to do with their wine, summer fruits, and oil?
options: Gather and store them in vessels
questions.correctAnswer: Gather and store them in vessels
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:10 instructs the people to gather their produce and store it in vessels while dwelling in their cities.

questions.question: Which figure warned Gedaliah about a plot to kill him, according to the text?
questions.correctAnswer: Johanan the son of Kareah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:14 shows that Johanan warns Gedaliah about the assassination plot by Ishmael sent by King Baalis.

questions.question: How did Gedaliah respond to Johanan's proposal to kill Ishmael secretly?
options: He forbade it, saying Johanan spoke falsely
He agreed and planned the assassination
questions.correctAnswer: He forbade it, saying Johanan spoke falsely
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:16 records Gedaliah refusing Johanan's request and declaring the accusation against Ishmael as false.

questions.question: What literary device is prominent in the structure of Gedaliah’s reassurance to the people about serving the Chaldeans?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Gedaliah’s speech in Jeremiah 40:9 uses parallelism common in Hebrew literature to emphasize trust and obedience to Babylonian rule.

questions.question: The Hebrew word translated 'loose' in Jeremiah 40:4, referring to Jeremiah’s chains, implies what about God’s providence?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereignty in delivering Jeremiah
questions.explanation: The verb in Jeremiah 40:4 indicates divine intervention through Nebuzaradan’s action, showing God’s control over Jeremiah’s fate.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 40’s depiction of Gedaliah’s governance foreshadow later biblical themes?
questions.correctAnswer: Remnant leadership and hope restoration
questions.explanation: Gedaliah’s role as governor over remnants in Jeremiah 40 echoes the biblical theme of remnant preservation and hope seen throughout prophetic literature.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah was forced to go to Babylon with Nebuzaradan after being freed from chains.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:4 clearly states that Jeremiah was given the choice to go to Babylon or remain in the land.

questions.question: The historical context of Jeremiah 40 includes the aftermath of which major event?
options: The destruction of Jerusalem by Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: The destruction of Jerusalem by Babylon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40 opens after Nebuzaradan has taken captives from Jerusalem, marking the destruction of the city in 586 BCE.

questions.question: What does the presence of the captains and their men coming to Gedaliah suggest about the political situation in Judah?
options: A fragmented but hopeful remnant leadership
questions.correctAnswer: A fragmented but hopeful remnant leadership
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:7-8 depicts military leaders rallying around Gedaliah, indicating a remnant trying to maintain order under Babylonian oversight.

questions.question: Which Old Testament theme is reinforced by Gedaliah’s instruction to serve the king of Babylon?
options: The hope for a Davidic king
questions.correctAnswer: Submission to God-ordained authority
questions.explanation: Gedaliah’s advice in Jeremiah 40:9 reflects the biblical theme that foreign rulers may be instruments of God’s judgment and should be respected.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 40 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 40 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary reason given for the calamity that has come upon Jerusalem and Judah according to Jeremiah 40?
options: They have sinned against the LORD and not obeyed His voice
They were conquered by a stronger army
They failed to build a strong defense wall
questions.correctAnswer: They have sinned against the LORD and not obeyed His voice
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:3 states that the calamity came because "ye have sinned against the LORD, and have not obeyed his voice." This aligns with biblical theology that sin and disobedience bring judgment (cf. Deuteronomy 28:15, Romans 1:18, Hebrews 12:6, and 2 Chronicles 36:16).

questions.question: What choice was Jeremiah given by Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard?
options: To go with him to Babylon or to go wherever he wished in the land
To return to Jerusalem or be executed
To stay in Ramah or be taken to Babylon
To serve the king of Babylon or be sold as a slave
questions.correctAnswer: To go with him to Babylon or to go wherever he wished in the land
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:4 records that Jeremiah was freed from chains and given the option to go to Babylon or go wherever he thought best in the land, demonstrating God's sovereign allowance of human free will within His providence (cf. Joshua 24:15, Proverbs 16:9, Acts 18:21, and Revelation 3:20).

questions.question: Who was appointed governor over the cities of Judah by the king of Babylon?
questions.correctAnswer: Gedaliah son of Ahikam
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:5 and 40:7 show Gedaliah son of Ahikam was made governor by the king of Babylon. This reflects God's use of foreign rulers to accomplish His judgments and plans (cf. Isaiah 10:5, Daniel 2:21, Romans 13:1, and Acts 17:26).

questions.question: What was Gedaliah's message to the captains and their men regarding serving the Chaldeans?
options: Fear not to serve the Chaldeans; dwell in the land and it shall be well with you
Rebel against the Chaldeans to regain your land
Flee to Egypt to escape the Chaldeans
Build a new army to overthrow the Chaldeans
questions.correctAnswer: Fear not to serve the Chaldeans; dwell in the land and it shall be well with you
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:9 records Gedaliah's oath encouraging peace and submission to Babylonian rule for their welfare. Submission to ruling authorities is a biblical principle (cf. Romans 13:1-7, 1 Peter 2:13-17, Proverbs 21:1, and Jeremiah 27:6).

questions.question: Where did Gedaliah choose to dwell to serve the Chaldeans?
questions.correctAnswer: Mizpah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:6 and 40:10 state Gedaliah dwelt at Mizpah as the center of his governance. Mizpah served as a strategic and symbolic location post-destruction, showing God's providence in leadership placement (cf. Judges 20:1, 1 Samuel 10:17, Jeremiah 31:6, and 2 Chronicles 34:9).

questions.question: What was the response of the Jews living in Moab, Ammon, Edom, and other countries when they heard about Gedaliah's appointment?
options: They returned to Judah and gathered much wine and summer fruits
They refused to return and remained in exile
They planned to rebel against the Babylonians
questions.correctAnswer: They returned to Judah and gathered much wine and summer fruits
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:11-12 indicates many Jews returned from various lands to Judah to join Gedaliah, highlighting God's mercy in preserving a remnant (cf. Isaiah 11:11-12, Ezekiel 37:21, Romans 11:5, and Luke 1:54).

questions.question: Who warned Gedaliah about a plot against his life, and whom was it said to be from?
options: Johanan and captains warned that Baalis, king of the Ammonites, sent Ishmael
Jeremiah warned that Nebuchadnezzar planned to kill Gedaliah
Ishmael warned Gedaliah of a Babylonian conspiracy
The people warned Gedaliah about a Babylonian rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: Johanan and captains warned that Baalis, king of the Ammonites, sent Ishmael
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:14 records Johanan informing Gedaliah of Baalis sending Ishmael to kill him. This episode illustrates political intrigue and the danger of alliances (cf. 2 Kings 24:2, Nehemiah 6:1-14, Psalm 31:13, and John 11:53).

questions.question: What was Gedaliah's response to the suggestion that Ishmael be killed secretly?
options: He refused, saying Johanan spoke falsely of Ishmael
He agreed to the plan immediately
He fled the city to avoid the danger
questions.correctAnswer: He refused, saying Johanan spoke falsely of Ishmael
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:15-16 shows Gedaliah rejecting the assassination plan and defending Ishmael's innocence. This teaches the virtue of trust and restraint, consistent with biblical calls for justice and peace (cf. Proverbs 3:5-6, Matthew 5:44, Romans 12:17-19, and James 1:19).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 40 reveal about God's sovereignty in the midst of human political events?
options: God uses foreign rulers like Nebuchadnezzar and Gedaliah to accomplish His purposes
God is powerless over political affairs
God only intervenes miraculously, not through rulers
God abandons His people in exile
questions.correctAnswer: God uses foreign rulers like Nebuchadnezzar and Gedaliah to accomplish His purposes
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40 shows Nebuzaradan and the Babylonian king acting under God's sovereign plan (cf. Daniel 4:17, Romans 13:1, Isaiah 45:1, and Proverbs 21:1). This affirms God's control over history and human rulers.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 40, what theological truth is taught regarding the consequences of sin and God's justice?
options: Sin results in judgment but God remains faithful to His covenant promises
Sin has no real consequences if one repents later
God ignores sin in favor of mercy alone
Judgment is arbitrary and unrelated to human actions
questions.correctAnswer: Sin results in judgment but God remains faithful to His covenant promises
questions.explanation: The chapter reflects that sin leads to exile and judgment (Jeremiah 40:3), yet God preserves a remnant through Gedaliah (Jeremiah 40:11-12), showing His justice and mercy (cf. Ezekiel 18:30-32, Lamentations 3:22-23, Romans 11:29, and 2 Timothy 2:13).

questions.question: How does the role of Gedaliah in this chapter contribute to the biblical doctrine of the remnant?
options: Gedaliah governs the remaining people, representing God's preservation of a faithful remnant
Gedaliah leads a rebellion against Babylon
Gedaliah abandons the people to exile
Gedaliah is a false leader rejected by God
questions.correctAnswer: Gedaliah governs the remaining people, representing God's preservation of a faithful remnant
questions.explanation: Gedaliah's governorship over those left in the land (Jeremiah 40:6-7) illustrates God's mercy in preserving a remnant for future restoration (cf. Isaiah 10:20-22, Micah 2:12, Romans 11:5, and Zephaniah 3:13).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 40 teach about human free will in the context of divine judgment?
options: Jeremiah was given the freedom to choose where to go after release
God forced Jeremiah to go to Babylon against his will
All people are predestined without choice
Human decisions are insignificant in God's plan
questions.correctAnswer: Jeremiah was given the freedom to choose where to go after release
questions.explanation: Nebuzaradan offers Jeremiah the choice to go to Babylon or stay (Jeremiah 40:4), showing that God allows human freedom within His sovereign judgments (cf. Joshua 24:15, Deuteronomy 30:19, Proverbs 16:9, and Galatians 5:13).

questions.question: Which of the following best expresses the ecclesiological lesson from Jeremiah 40 regarding leadership after judgment?
options: God raises leaders like Gedaliah to shepherd His people in difficult times
Leaders must always be of royal lineage
Ecclesiastical leadership is irrelevant after exile
Only prophets can lead God's people
questions.correctAnswer: God raises leaders like Gedaliah to shepherd His people in difficult times
questions.explanation: Gedaliah's role as governor after Jerusalem's fall (Jeremiah 40:5-6) reflects God's provision of leadership for the covenant community, consistent with biblical patterns of God appointing leaders for His people (cf. Exodus 18:21, 1 Samuel 16:1-13, Acts 20:28, and Hebrews 13:17).

questions.question: What does the interaction between Johanan and Gedaliah in Jeremiah 40 reveal about discernment and trust in leadership?
options: Gedaliah trusted Ishmael and rejected Johanan's secret plan, emphasizing caution and integrity
Johanan's plot was supported by Gedaliah
Gedaliah ignored all warnings and acted recklessly
Johanan was appointed co-governor by Gedaliah
questions.correctAnswer: Gedaliah trusted Ishmael and rejected Johanan's secret plan, emphasizing caution and integrity
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 40:15-16 shows Gedaliah's refusal of the assassination plot based on his trust in Ishmael, illustrating the biblical call for wise discernment and rejection of violence (cf. Proverbs 3:5-6, Matthew 10:16, Romans 12:17-21, and Titus 3:2).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 40 contribute to our understanding of God's attribute of justice?
options: God's justice brings consequences for sin but preserves hope through a remnant
God's justice is harsh and without mercy
God only punishes the wicked without any restoration
questions.correctAnswer: God's justice brings consequences for sin but preserves hope through a remnant
questions.explanation: The chapter shows that sin led to exile (judgment) but God preserved a remnant under Gedaliah (Jeremiah 40:3, 11), reflecting a balanced justice that includes punishment and mercy (cf. Psalm 89:14, Isaiah 30:18, Romans 3:26, and Lamentations 3:31-33).
